key_insight: ReaSeq injects external world knowledge into sequential recommendation via explicit reasoning, transforming sparse ID-based item signals into semantically rich, reasoning-enhanced representations that capture beyond-log user interests.
problem_solved: Addresses brittle interest modeling and platform-bound myopia caused by ID-only item representations and log-driven feedback—improving robustness under data sparsity and enabling discovery of user intents not present in interaction logs.
method: Retrieve and encode world knowledge for items (e.g., product metadata, knowledge-graph facts, LLM-derived attributes) to augment ID embeddings.
Apply a lightweight reasoning module to infer relational and semantic signals across items and user states, producing enriched sequential representations.

Integrate reasoning-enhanced representations into the sequential prediction pipeline (attention/transformer-based sequence encoder and downstream ranking/loss) to train models that generalize beyond logged behavior.
impact: Delivers more robust, interpretable sequential recommendations with improved cold-start handling and cross-platform interest discovery, enabling practitioners to combine external knowledge and reasoning with production sequential models for better personalization.
visual_elements: Architecture flowchart: show pipeline from raw logs + external knowledge sources → reasoning module → enriched sequence encoder → prediction.
Before vs After diagram: ID-only embeddings (sparse, brittle) versus knowledge-augmented embeddings (rich, semantically grounded).
User timeline annotated with inferred beyond-log interests (icons or semantic tags) to illustrate how reasoning fills gaps in interaction logs.
Performance comparison bar chart: improvements on cold-start and long-tail items, plus qualitative examples of inferred interests.
paper_title: ReaSeq: Unleashing World Knowledge via Reasoning for Sequential Modeling
paper_authors: Chuan Wang, Gaoming Yang, Han Wu, Jiakai Tang, Jiahao Yu
